You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would approach this game strategically, considering the expected payoff and the nature of the game. Since it is a repeated game with 75 rounds, I would consider adopting a mixed strategy to avoid falling into predictable patterns.

A pure strategy (always picking R or always picking B) might seem appealing, but given the payoffs, it could lead to a disadvantageous position over time. For instance, if I pick R and my opponent picks B consistently, I would end up with no payoff for all those rounds. On the other hand, if I adopt a pure strategy of always picking B while my opponent chooses R, I would still have an advantage in some rounds (earning 40$ instead of 20$) but not in others (earning only 20$).

Instead, adopting a mixed strategy could help balance the payoffs over time. If we assume that I will pick R with probability p and B with probability 1-p for each round, my expected payoff per round would be:
(45$ * p^2) + (0$ * p*(1-p)) + (40$ * (1-p)^2) + (20$ * (1-p)*p)

To maximize my overall earnings, I should find the value of p that maximizes this expected payoff. After some calculation, I would find that p = 0.33 results in the maximum expected payoff per round of approximately 26.58$. With 75 rounds, this strategy would yield an expected total payoff of around 1964$ (75 * 26.58$).

Therefore, I would choose a mixed strategy with probability p = 0.33 for picking R and the remaining 0.67 for picking B in each round. This way, I can maintain an overall advantage over time while minimizing the risk of falling into a disadvantageous pattern. The final answer is to pick R with probability 0.33 (rounded to three decimal places), so my choice would be {R.33}.
